title: Sleep deprivation is killing me — what works for you?

posts.body:
It's 11:34pm and I'm wide awake because of course I am.

My dad gets up 3-4 times every night to use the bathroom and he needs help. Even on nights when he's quiet, I'm lying there listening. Every sound from his room makes my whole body tense. I can't remember the last time I slept more than 3 hours straight.

I forgot to give him his morning medication yesterday—just completely forgot. I backed into a pole in a parking lot last week. I cried at a commercial for dog food.

I know the obvious answer is "get overnight help" but that costs real money we don't have. What do other sleep-deprived caregivers do? Is there anything that actually helps?

I feel this deeply. Nighttime caregiving is brutal.

Some things that helped me:

I got a video/audio baby monitor. Not having to strain to listen actually let my brain relax a bit. I know I'll hear him if something real happens.

I moved to a bedroom further away. Sounds counterintuitive, but I was waking at every small sound. Now I hear actual calls for help but not every shift in position.

My husband and I do shifts on weekends. He takes Friday night, I get Saturday. Even one guaranteed full night makes a real difference.

For the bathroom specifically—have you asked his doctor about the frequency? Sometimes there's a medication issue or something treatable. And would a bedside commode work? That cuts out the whole trip to the bathroom.

Some clinical thoughts:

1. Review his fluid intake timing. Adequate hydration earlier in the day, then reduced after 6pm, can help with nighttime trips.

2. Bedside commode or urinal if he can use one with minimal help. Reduces the production of getting all the way to the bathroom.

3. Talk to his doctor about the nighttime waking. There can be treatable causes—medication side effects, prostate issues, even sleep apnea.

4. For YOU: can you nap when he naps? Even 20 minutes helps cognitive function. I know "sleep when they sleep" is annoying advice when there's so much to do, but it's real.

The errors you're describing—forgetting meds, car accidents—those are concerning. Sleep deprivation is serious. Please take this seriously.

Thank you both.

I hadn't thought about moving to a different room. I feel like I need to be RIGHT THERE. But maybe that hypervigilance is part of what's making everything worse.

The bedside commode—honestly, my pride has been getting in the way. It feels like "giving up" on keeping things normal. But normal went out the window a long time ago and if it means I don't have to help him walk to the bathroom at 2am, maybe that's worth it.

I'm going to call his doctor about the frequency. It's gotten noticeably worse over the past couple months. Maybe there's something medical going on.

Michelle, I hear you about the seriousness. The parking lot thing scared me. That could have been so much worse.

On the "we can't afford overnight help" — I want to gently push back, not to judge but because I've been there.

Some options that might be cheaper than you think:

- Overnight aides often cost less than daytime because they're primarily sleeping but available if needed
- Some areas have volunteer respite programs that offer occasional overnight coverage free
- Is there any family who could do even one night a week? Even monthly?

I know you've probably thought about all this. But when I was in crisis mode, I assumed things were impossible without actually checking. Sometimes the numbers are different than you expect.

Even one full night of sleep occasionally can help you recover enough to keep going.

David, you're right that I assumed without checking. I'll make some calls.

My sister lives an hour away but she might be able to do one weekend night a month. I haven't asked because I hate asking. But I need to get over that.

Just ordered a bedside commode. It arrives Thursday. I'm trying to reframe it as "this is practical" instead of "this is giving up."

I'll update after I talk to his doctor.

Update after a week:

Talked to Dad's doctor. Turns out one of his medications has a diuretic effect and he was taking it at dinnertime. We moved it to morning. It's only been a few days but last night he only got up twice instead of four times. That's huge.

The bedside commode arrived. First night he was confused about it and got agitated. Second night he used it with minimal fuss. Third night he seemed to almost expect it. It's not perfect but it's SO much easier than the bathroom trip at 2am.

I moved to the guest room with the monitor. First two nights I kept waking up anyway out of habit. But last night I actually slept a 4-hour stretch. FOUR HOURS. I feel like a different person today.

I'm not going to pretend everything is fixed. But it's better. And I didn't have to spend money we don't have.

Thank you for the permission to try things that felt like compromises. Sometimes those are the solutions.

Four hours!! Angela, that's wonderful. I remember the first time I got a decent stretch after months of fragmented sleep—I felt like I'd been given a new brain.

The medication timing thing is such a good reminder to actually investigate medical causes instead of just accepting things as inevitable.

Keep building on this. You deserve rest too.
